array.string: Take a deep breath.
Count to 10.
Ask yourself if it’s really worth getting upset over. Will it matter in a week, month, or year?
Walk away from the situation for a few minutes.
Think about what you want to say before you say it……….wait at least 5 seconds.
Take a few moments to stop the angry statements running through your head. Replace them with calming statements.
Visualize being in a peaceful place.
Avoid things that always make you mad (if possible.)
Take a deep breath.
Try to relax your body, stretch or shake off any tension.
Close your eyes and count to 10.
Take a few moments to stop the angry statements running through your head. Replace them with calming statements.
Visualize being in a peaceful place.
Focus on controlling your anger first before trying to problem-solve.
Walk away from the situation for a few minutes.
Think about what you want to say before you say it……….wait at least 5 seconds.
Share your feelings calmly using “I” statements.
Don’t raise your voice, if the other person begins to speak loudly, speak more softly in response.
Remember that you can’t take back what you say. Will you regret it later?
Set goals—short term and long term.
Focus forward, not on the past.
Accept the things you can’t change.
Take control of the way you look at things.
Make a blessings list.
Exercise & eat right.
Maintain a consistent sleeping schedule.
Talk to someone about how you are feeling.
Listen to music.
Write your feelings in a journal.
Do something nice for someone else.
Doing nothing will only feed into your depression and only make you more depressed.
Talk to someone.
Write your feelings in a journal.
Do something nice for someone else.
Make a list of your best qualities.
Identify supportive people in your life.
Take care of yourself.
Put your best foot forward.
Make an apology.
Spend time playing with a pet.
Try to identify an activity that you can get involved with to meet others with your same interests (music, sports, volunteering at an animal shelter, theatre, etc.)

dict.key: Depression and feeling confused in life

array.string: Identify what is causing your confusion.
Who can help answer your questions?
Set goals and focus forward.
Be patient.
Talk and or write about what’s confusing you – repeatedly, if you need to.
Take a break from the confusion when possible. Relax and recharge.
Identify things that are meaningful to you, what activities make you feel like you are making a difference in the world.
Identify where your stress is coming from.
Focus on the here & now.
Eat well and sleep well.
Manage your time.
Make lists.
Set goals.
Accept the things you can’t change.
Take control of the way you look at things.
Keep a worry journal. When you begin to worry about something, write it down. Sometimes it helps to get it out of your head and written on paper.
Talk to someone who can help you process what you are going through.
Stay out of pointless drama!
Learn to say "no."
Think about what you want to say before you say it……….wait at least 5 seconds.
Share your feelings calmly using “I” statements.
Don’t raise your voice.
Remind yourself that you can't take back what you say. Will you regret it later?
Take responsibility for your behavior. If you make a mistake, correct it. Apologize, if necessary. People are less likely to be mad at you if you own up to the mistake.
Forgive yourself for making mistake or for your imperfections.
Set yourself up for success. Set some small, realistic goals that you can accomplish.

Learn to say positive things to yourself. Instead of cutting yourself down, build yourself up. Tell yourself that you are a good person, that you will keep trying, or that you are going to remain calm.
Learn to solve your own problems. Realize that when you make good decisions you gain more control over what happens to you.
Respect yourself. Stick with what you know is right. Don’t let others talk you into doing something for the sake of popularity or status.
Be friendly, helpful, and cooperative; that’s what really counts.
Learn to be assertive. Being assertive can help you get what you want without hurting others or making a scene.
Give yourself 10 minutes twice a day to worry about things…….after that, whenever you notice yourself worrying, tell yourself it will still be there tomorrow.
Keep a worry journal. When you begin to worry about something, write it down. Sometimes it helps to get it out of your head and written on paper.
Take a deep breath. Try to relax.
Close your eyes and count to 10.
Replace negative statements running through your mind with reality statements and calming thoughts.
Visualize being in a peaceful place.
Get some exercise.
Embarrassment is a result of negative thoughts we have about ourselves or situations. Everybody is embarrassed sometimes and that’s okay!
Use positive self-talk when you begin to feel embarrassment. Tell yourself that you are a good person, that you will keep trying, or that you are going to remain calm.
Do something nice for someone else. Whenever you help someone else, you take the focus off of you, and can help yourself feel better.
Take a deep breath.
Count to 10.
Ask yourself if it’s really worth getting upset over. Will it matter in a week, month, or year?
